ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Fairness metrics and algorithms and how to think about how they relate to society, not as something purely theoretical. Is data being fed into models biased? how do we account for them? it is actually a very good class at the intersection of social sciences and computer science. Prof is very knowledgeable and has done a lot in his career.
Fair algorithmic design: strategies to combat bias, definitions of fairness, handling intersectionality, etc...
I gained general idea about societal impact about algorithms.
The fundamentals algorithms used in a social setting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The project is kind of hands off and is the main thing of the class. There are some midterm reports/deadlines, but it is mostly up to you and your group to do the project on your own time.
I like the project-based structure of the course. I appreciated the opportunity to work with my classmates to tackle an algorithmically driven and societally impactful issue of our own.
Interesting material, lacks guidance on projects, very self-driven
The lectures covered a lot aspects in this area. The theory parts was a bit hard to me to comprehend.

Strengths: the scope.
Weaknesses: it doesn't give us enough technical/mathematical background.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, i think it's an important class in the field of AI that really forces you to consider how our society is impacted by the digital age and as algorithms are being more widely implemented, the subject matter of this class is very important. It is also a very low workload class, with the project being the main assessment of the class.
Yes! This course is engaging, not overwhelming workload, lots of important information whether or not you're planning to work in tech.

Really did not like this class despite my interest in the material. I expected much more of a seminar format given the nature of the topics, but instead, each class was nearly two hours of Professor Vishnoi with little to no student interaction. I also was really disappointed in the nature of assignments for the course. Students are expected to form groups for a final project on the first day of class, with very unclear expectations as to what examples of final deliverables should be and how the project will be graded. Throughout the semester, Professor Vishnoi's feedback was bizarre and unhelpful: it felt as if the goal posts were constantly changing, and each time we addressed his issues he would come up with a new critique. The lack of an actual rubric for this assignment definitely fed into this uncertainty and it was impossible to tell what we were being evaluated on. Professor Vishnoi also clearly demonstrated he was not actually reading our submitted reports, as he frequently came to meetings and asked us to include content that was already in the material we submitted. He also never once provided written feedback or line edits despite his insistence that we submit both written reports and give oral presentations. Instead, we would receive a 30 second (at most) oral blurb of feedback and be expected to come see him outside of class for additional notes. Overall, the feedback on the project felt subjective and unhelpful, which was disappointing given the central nature of this assignment to the course. I would stay away: student engagement in the course was low and I felt instruction was poor overall.
Yes only to people interested in this area.
It is a great class for the right person. It is a mix of computer science and social science/politics.
